Super Hexagon is a simple, yet very addictive game. You take control of a triangle positioned in the middle of the screen and have to dodge the walls coming your way. The game has a total of six levels (three normal levels and three 'hyper modes'), each of which presents you with new patterns and challenges. If you survive for sixty seconds, you essentially 'complete' a stage and unlock its hyper mode, although it goes on until you die, which allows skilled players to achieve high scores and compete against each other. Due to the overall difficulty of the game, patience and practice are very important factors. If you want to challenge yourself with a fun and hard game, then Super Hexagon is for you!

Super Hexagon . A simplistic addiction. A small and short action-retro game.  The objective is to survive a minimum of 60 seconds (one minute) in a hexagonal world of collapsing walls. The player (you) are a tiny triangle that's free-roaming rather than stiff and static in motion, which adds a bit of a challenge to the game. In this game, upon first start, are three basic modes, nicknamed  Hexagon  (the easiest, apparently),  Hexagoner  (medium difficulty), and  Hexagonest  (the first hardest). Your time on these stages is your overall score, and after lasting one minute in the first three, you unlock a much more harder mode of the same stage ( Hexagon/er/est Hyper ). And if you wish to 'practice' for one of these difficulties, there's an Acrade mode under Options.   Review

Stephen King, in Storm of the Century , says 'Hell is repetition'. Well, folks, welcome to Hell.  Be prepared to restart the game after a few secs, 10-20 times in a minute. Rinse and repeat, again, again, again, until you're done - or good enough.  This game consists of 'only' 6 stages, I rather call them 'circles of Hell'. That ♥♥♥♥ It's hard. Very hard (already told it's HARD with capital letters?).   Theorically, this game could be completed in less than 10 minutes, if you are an autist, or have a great mind for detecting patterns, since each stage lasts 60 seconds (could be more, but 60 secs are the minimum needed to clear the stage, get the achievement and proceed to the next torture).  I've completed this game in 9-10 hours. You get used if you play hours and hours in one sitting. Your mind learns how to read and, most importantly, antecipate the patterns. It's all about patterns, folks. My results were way better when I turned the music off and started to listen Two Steps from Hell (name quite apropriate, but not intentional), by the way. The game's music might be a more adequate challenge for being quite disturbing (that's the idea, I guess), but it gaves me headaches.  That all said, this game is awesome for those looking for a mental challenge more than a game. Super Hexagon is hardly a game in the way the most are used to. It's more a competition between your brain, eyes and hands.   My final advice is to avoid to buy it in full price, Wait for a sale or bundle, since this game could - and will be - frustrating and gives you no reason to replay it when you finally finishes (its like breaking the chains).

Addicting but frustratingly flawed. How far you move is variable, and any given keypress might move you futher than, or not as far, as you intended. This inconsistency is prohibitive.  Also, the game is intentionally visually confusing, but it succeeds too well. I frequently believe I should have lost, but did not, and vice versa.  I am frequently unable to tell at which exact pixel my unit is located, and unable to move it in a reliable manner. This is a recipe for terrible. As a player of bullet hell games, I'm no stranger to moving small objects through obstacles within a distance of one pixel... This game could have been designed better.  That aside, the starting levels are always possible to beat- there is no 'chance' or 'luck', you win or lose on your skills alone, and I blame myself for more failures than I blame the game's design.  However, I'm convinced that the later levels can and do generate sequences where you are physically unable to win given the established mechanics, and they introduce an element of chance in a game that is supposed to rely on skill, which I'm sure is one of the seven deadly sins. For example, the 'camera' might angle around so you cannot see where the next turn is, as it often does in all levels, but the later levels move faster while the unit you control is always restricted to the same speed. Where you are in relation to where the next exit is purely chance, and you can't always get there in time.  But hey, I think I got this for 0.30USD. I can't complain, and it's a fairly reliable way to test and hone reflexes.

The game spins an epic tale of a lone hero trapped in the sixth dimension, desperately seeking an escape. He is relentlessly assaulted by the ruthless polygon tribes, and quickly develops a sense of despair towards the shapes. But while we thought the tribes were the enemy, there is, in fact, a much darker force at work here. In a dramatic turn of events, we learn that the tribes weren't malicious after all. The polygon people are in grave danger; the attacks on our hero were merely collateral damage in the much grander fight. In a heart-touching scene, we see a young quadrilateral display sympathy with a moving gesture of compassion towards our hero. These shapes are just as human as you or I. Our hero is faced with a choice: escape now, or attempt to save the polygon people? The former would be selfish, the latter would be impossible and surely suicide. But he is undaunted in his endeavor, and pushes forward against the forces of darkness. We see him progress through battlefields in a war between the very realities themselves. Red, Blue, Green, Purple, Black. The colors of armies all clash together in a fight for existence. He will end this. He has to end this. He trudges on, deeper and deeper into the angled abyss. Finally, our hero arrives at the gates to the domain of evil itself. Limbo. There's no turning back now. The battle seems endless. This realm's vertexes and angles are so ethereally plagued by darkness, it would drive a man mad within minutes. But our hero's will is as hard as iron. The enemy employs psychological warfare tactics, further progressing our hero's decent into insanity. A ubiquitous ocean of whispers never seems to cease ringing in his ears. 'Fifty-eight secondssss,' they taunt. Our hero arrives at the core. This is it. Failure now would mean the end of existence. Now, he must face the very essence of evil. The entity of fear, destruction, and all things unholy. Does he make it? Was he able to defeat the Evil, and push back their armies into oblivion? I don't know. We may never know the true fate of the polygon people of the sixth dimension. We may only hope that our hero was successful, and, if he wasn't, hope that the Evil never set foot into our own world. But I can tell you this: There is not black or white. There is not light or dark. Not reality or fantasy, nor life or death. There is only hexagon.

Their difficulty levels in the game are Hard, Harder, Hardest, Hardester, Hardestest, and Hardes♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, respectively. As the difficulties suggest, each level makes it harder to make it beyond 60 seconds by speeding up how quickly the walls come at you. Overall, it's very original and surprisingly fun. 9.5/10  Replay Value- This game is built so that every time you play the same level, it is different. In reality, the only things that are the same are the background colors, music, and difficulty/name. Never will you play the same level twice, which means that you can play for hundreds of hours experimenting with new stuff. And with 6 levels, it will keep you for a while. 10/10  Addiction and Difficulty- This game has a strange power I have never seen any other game come close to having- well, maybe except for Solitaire... anyways, this game is addicting as all heck. I tell you, I played this game every single day for 3 months. I kept coming back for more. Even long after I had beaten the game, I had kept coming back. This game is extremely difficult. Most people don't stay long after starting because they give up. However, it is genuine difficulty. It's not because of poor controls or level design, it's because they haven't practiced enough. Super Hexagon is a game of practice makes perfect. You cannot expect to be good at it right away. And with that, I commend it. For making people need to try over and over. 10/10  Graphics/Music- This game's 'graphics' Are pretty much just vectors set on a colorful spinning background. They're simple. They don't try to be amazing, since that's not what this game tries to do. They aren't the best, but what they lack, is makes up for in music. This game has an amazing soundtrack of a whole 3 songs. But these songs are amazing. In fact, 'Focus', the theme of Hyper Hexagonest and Hexagonest, is in my top 10 video game themes of all time. 10/10  Story- 10/10 Gameplay- 9.5/10 Addiction and Difficulty- 10/10 Replay Value- 10/10 Graphics/Music- 10/10 Total- 99/100- Go buy it NOW

Super Hexagon is a fun and addictive game that involves surviving for as long as possible as obstacles close in.  The player rotates a little outward facing triangular turtle (to borrow the Logo term) to avoid getting trapped by barriers.  The game features 6 difficulty levels total with 3 base levels and 'hyper' versions of each. A level is considered cleared if the player survives in it for at least 60 seconds.  Super Hexagon encourages - without frustration - better and better performances. Initially, surviving for over 15 seconds will seem like a great accomplishment while the 60 second goal is thought to be impossibly out of reach. The barrier patterns are randomly strung together with each playthrough. This allows for techniques to be developed without the need for rote learning. Along the way to 60 seconds the player will repeatedly attempt to improve upon the current best score. Doing so will be met with visual and audio rewards.  The game's minimalistic design is rounded out with brilliant subtleties. Only the front tip of the turtle must be kept out of harm's way, allowing the sides to make contact. The turtle has a terrific little wobble as it is moved left and right. The color changes and playing field rotation change between difficulty levels and also at different time marks within each level. On the most difficult level, shadows are used to pull off a pseudo 3D effect.  For controls, use WASD + spacebar or arrow keys + Enter. Use long continuous movements by pressing, holding, and releasing instead of repeated smaller movements.  Super Hexagon supports Steam cloud syncing and online leaderboards which can be filtered to only display the results of Steam friends.

This game costs less than a half a pint of beer in a bar. Or roughly the same amount of money (inflation corrected) you used to feed an arcade cabinet for one game when there still was real arcade games everywhere. But for 3€, you get to own the game, so of course you have to try it.  Don't let the videos scare you. They are not usually from the easiest level, Hexagon – which is, for decency reason, still labeled 'hard'. Hard it is, for normal person at least, but a challenge I suppose anyone can master given some time. Pretty soon you'll get to the flow and can live with the rotating camera and pulsating, flashing colors.  At point you get to level 4, Hyper Hexagon (which unlike level 3, Hexagonest, is not based on gimmicks and sudden camera rotation, it just throws stuff at you, very fast), it kinda like changes your perception of time. Suddenly you understand how much time there is in a second, how much can happen in a second, and still your brain somehow manages to react.  I, however, find it possible that it is physically impossible for me and many other people to complete this game. Time will tell.  The way the game loops the soundtrack is nice, it does not always start from the same part when you start a new game, which is nice since when you can't have your ♥♥♥♥ together and your flow going, you will be starting new games  a lot .  tl;dr: benchmark your brain!
